text:
I was just checking my P&L's this morning and noticed that one particular flumine strat on AWS Ubuntu had done well over the last 30 days or so...so i thought Id log into to check all looked ok disk space etc...
Everything looked good except I noticed that i had run that particular program via Pycharm rather than standalone...:grinning::man-facepalming:
So now im thinking, whether to just leave it running or stop it and run standalone... (I appreciate that the former is not good practice and maybe slower, but what would you do?) Thanks

elements.text:
I was just checking my P&L's this morning and noticed that one particular flumine strat on AWS Ubuntu had done well over the last 30 days or so...so i thought Id log into to check all looked ok disk space etc...
Everything looked good except I noticed that i had run that particular program via Pycharm rather than standalone...
So now im thinking, whether to just leave it running or stop it and run standalone... (I appreciate that the former is not good practice and maybe slower, but what would you do?) Thanks

text: I doubt it's that much slower tbh (I do sometimes feel the way it writes the logs sometimes slows it down) however confirming it actually is and then understanding why it is performing better always sends me down an interesting path

elements.text: I doubt it's that much slower tbh (I do sometimes feel the way it writes the logs sometimes slows it down) however confirming it actually is and then understanding why it is performing better always sends me down an interesting path

text: Thanks Liam, Im going away for a few weeks so i'll prob just leave it as it is for the time being, I might even run a duplicate strat in parallel standalone (only smallish stakes) and then compare when i get home..cheers
